THE VIDEOGRAPHER: Good morning. We are on
the record.
This marks the beginning of Volume II,
Media 1, in the deposition of Edward Kellar.
The case caption is Edward Kellar, et al.,
versus Central Investments, et al. The case number
is 19-CV-360733 venued in the Superior Court of the
State of California for the County of Santa Clara.
Today's date is April 19th, 2024. And the
time on the monitor is 10:17 a.m. Pacific time.
We are located at the offices of Hopkins &
Carley located at 70 South First Street, San --
excuse me -- San Jose, California.
My name is Antonio Woodward, certified
legal video specialist for the County of Santa Clara
representing Media Frontier Video Productions.
Telephone number, (408) 279-2740.
Your certified stenographic reporter is Kim
Meierotto representing Kim Meierotto, CSR.
Counsel, please state your name, your
office and whom you represent in this action.
MR. ELLENBERG: Steve Ellenberg for
defendant Accounting Data Associates. And on the
Zoom for at least some portion of this deposition is
my colleague Andrew Ditlevsen. We are both of
Hopkins & Carley.
MR. KEEGAN: I'm Bill Keegan. I represent
the defendants, all the defendants, other than
Accounting Data.
MS. PALLEN: Kimberly Pallen on behalf of
Mr. Kellar and the other plaintiffs. And also on
Zoom on behalf of Mr. Kellar and the other
plaintiffs are Dean Nicyper, Tyler Goss, and Steve
Wilson, all with Withers Bergman LLP except for
Mr. Wilson who is with Haynes Boone.
THE VIDEOGRAPHER: The court reporter may
now administer the oath.
--oOo--
EDWARD KELLAR,
called as a witness, after having been first duly
sworn by the Certified Shorthand Reporter to tell
the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the
truth, testified as follows:
--oOo--
EXAMINATION BY MR. ELLENBERG (continued):
Q. Mr. Kellar, I introduced myself to you this
morning, and we met over Zoom --
A. Yes.
Q. -- back in I think September of 2022.
You've had your deposition taken before. Correct?
A. That's correct.
Q. And how are you feeling today?
A. I feel good, yeah.
Q. Is there any reason that you're aware of
that you cannot give your best, most truthful
testimony today?
A. Nope, can't think of anything.
Q. Mr. Kellar, how old are you?
A. 36. Some think I'm 81.
Q. And you have been involved in real estate
for how many years?
A. 50, 60 years.
Q. If someone asked you what did you do for a
living or what do you do for a living, how would you
respond?
A. I would tell them that I'm in real estate
management and investments, uh-huh.
Q. And tell me what someone in real estate
management does. What's the kind of work, just
50,000-foot view.
MS. PALLEN: Objection. Vague.
But you can answer. Go ahead.
THE WITNESS: I'm sorry.
MS. PALLEN: I said objection, vague. But
you can go ahead and answer.
THE WITNESS: I'm sorry, Kim.
Well, in real estate management you manage
complexes. You fix up complexes. And I guess
that's the two main roles.
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. Do you consider in real estate management
to involve managing investors and partners?
A. Yes, I've done that, uh-huh.
Q. And you consider yourself to be a real
estate investor as well. Is that right?
A. Yes.
Q. For how long have you done real estate
investment?
A. Since I guess 1971. Yeah, you remember
that year, 1971.
Q. What got you into real estate investment?
A. Actually excuse me. It's 1970. 1970. I'm
sorry.
Q. We're not going to hold you to '70 or '71.
I don't think that's the key fact in the case.
A. Okay. All right. I want to be truthful
here now. She told me to be.
Q. And we want you to be.
A. Okay.
Q. What got you into real estate investment?
A. I used to work at Lockheed. An engineer
come up to me and he said, "Well, didn't pay any
taxes last year." I was a tech. I said, "You make
more than me, and you don't -- you don't pay taxes?"
He said, "Yeah. You want to hear about it?"
Well, he was a real estate guy on the side.
So because of working at Lockheed and associate
there, I got into real estate.
Q. Do you consider yourself to be a
sophisticated real estate investor?
A. I don't consider myself to be at anything,
associated with -- no, I don't know. I just learned
to know the business.
Q. Have you done real estate investment since
1970 or '71 till the present?
A. Yes.
Q. And tell me the kinds of things that a real
estate investor does.
MS. PALLEN: Calls for speculation.
But if you know, go ahead and answer.
THE WITNESS: Well, I mean --
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. Let me ask a better question.
Tell me the kinds of things you did and
continue to do as a real estate investor.
A. Yeah. Well, I've always been into buying
and selling. I've always been into buying mostly
fixer-upper complexes, turning them around, raising
the rents, refinancing them or eventually selling
them as a syndicator for the people that I represent
and myself.
Q. What is a syndicator?
A. That's like Dick Gregersen, putting
together The Highlander project with two different
partnerships. That's a syndicator.
Q. So in your career as a real estate
investor, you've formed partnerships?
A. Yes, sir.
Q. Have you formed LLCs?
A. Yes, sir.
Q. And those partnerships or LLCs or groups of
investors get together to acquire or sell real
property; is that right?
A. That's correct, uh-huh.
Q. Do you have to deal with lawyers as a real
estate investor?
A. Oh, yeah, uh-huh.
Q. And you have to deal with contracts?
A. Sure.
Q. In your career as a real estate investor,
how many contracts do you think you've had to
review?
MS. PALLEN: Objection. Calls for
speculation.
THE WITNESS: I really don't know. More
than -- a lot. A lot.
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. Was it your practice to read the contracts
that you would sign?
A. Oh, of course.
Q. And if you had any questions, ask about --
about them?
A. Sure.
Q. In your career as a real estate investor,
have you borrowed money?
A. Yes.
Q. Either personally or as part of a
syndicate?
A. Yes. You have to get first mortgages.
MS. PALLEN: You have to get what? I'm
sorry.
THE WITNESS: You have to get first
mortgages --
MS. PALLEN: First mortgages.
THE WITNESS: -- on properties, uh-huh.
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. Did you ever get second mortgages?
A. Sure.
Q. Have you ever gotten third mortgages?
A. Don't recall.
Q. Would you agree that borrowing money is
part of the everyday work of someone involved in
real estate investments?
A. Um-hum, certainly.
Q. You did ultimately answer that question
with "certainly." I just want to caution you --
A. Yes, yes.
Q. -- just to use words. You got it.
A. Yes, yes.
Q. And now I'm going to give you that other
instruction.
A. Okay.
Q. Let's not try -- let's try not to speak
over each other.
A. Okay.
Q. So I'm ADA's lawyer, but I also consider
myself to be the protector of the court reporter.
A. Got it.
Q. I want to -- we want to make her job
easier. It may be the only thing that we both
should have in common, but we want to make her job
easier.
A. Take care of Kim.
Q. In your career as a real estate investor,
have you loaned money?
A. I really don't know. I do what it takes to
make a deal.
Q. I mean, is it your experience that
borrowing and lending money is part of the things
that a real estate investor should be familiar with?
MS. PALLEN: Objection. Vague and
ambiguous. But that's fine. Go ahead.
THE WITNESS: Yes.
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. Now, I recall from the first session of
your deposition you indicated that you had loaned
money to relatives in the past. Is that correct?
MS. PALLEN: Objection. That potentially
misstates testimony. I don't remember that.
But you can answer.
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. Let me ask it more broadly. I don't want
to -- have you ever loaned money to anyone?
A. To anyone?
Q. Yeah.
A. Oh, yeah, yeah, yes.
Q. Have you loaned money to friends?
A. Sure, yes.
Q. And have you loaned money to relatives?
A. Yes.
Q. When you loan money to friends, do you --
is it your practice to charge interest?
A. No.
Q. And when you loan money to relatives, is it
your practice to charge interest?
A. No.
Q. Have you had the experience of any entity
in which you were a syndicator loaning money to
another entity in which you were a syndicator?
MS. PALLEN: Objection. Asked and
answered.
But go ahead.
THE WITNESS: No, I don't recall that,
huh-uh.
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. Was it -- is it your practice over the last
70 -- what -- trying to think whether it's been --
MS. PALLEN: 54.
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. -- over the last -- I like to just figure
it out based on my age -- over the last 50-some-odd
years to keep track of where interest rates are?
A. Oh, of course, yes.
Q. And there -- you agree that there were
times in the '70s that interest rates were very
high?
A. Yes, they were.
Q. And have there been times where interest
rates are low?
A. Yes.
Q. Do you -- are you able to call up where
interest rates were in the 2010s?
A. No. Seemed like they were high, but I
don't recall exactly. I don't, huh-uh.
Q. Is there a source you would go to if I said
to you, Mr. Kellar, can you tell me what the
interest rates were for federal fund rates in 2015?
Is there a source you would go to?
A. Well, probably go to the web for a question
like that, yes.
Q. What would you type into the Internet?
A. I don't know. I'm not really -- real high
on technology and everything, so I've never tried to
do that, but I don't know.
Q. Would you agree that the federal funds rate
is a good place to start in terms of figuring out
where interest rates were?
A. Yeah, it's kind of the key, the basic rate,
yes, uh-huh.
Q. And my understanding is the Wall Street
Journal publishes a regular interest rate index?
A. They have primary -- yeah, uh-huh. Yes,
they do.
Q. And what -- would the Wall Street Journal
tell you what the prime rate is?
A. You know, I just had no need recently to
key into that, so I don't know.
Q. I'm going to ask you to mark as Exhibit 4.
(Exhibit No. 4 is marked.)
MS. PALLEN: I guess we can't have the
people on Zoom able to see this, huh.
Does this have a Bates number?
MR. ELLENBERG: This one did not.
MR. KEEGAN: Get a Bates number in a
second.
MS. PALLEN: For the record this is a
document that's been titled --
MR. ELLENBERG: I was going to put it on
the record.
MS. PALLEN: Okay.
MR. ELLENBERG: I'll take care of that.
MS. PALLEN: Just want to make sure they
have an opportunity --
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. Yes. I mean, it looks to me like the
offering memorandum for the Highlander. Are we
okay? I'm waiting for the videographer. We're
okay.
So I've had marked as Exhibit 4 a document
that's entitled "The Highlander, an investment
opportunity by Accounting Data Associates, Inc."
And I would ask you, Mr. Kellar, to take as much
time as you need to look through this document and
let me know the answer to the question, have you
ever seen it before?
A. (Reviewing document.)
MS. PALLEN: Did you get the Bates number,
Bill?
MR. KEEGAN: It's taking longer than I
thought.
(Discussion off record.)
THE WITNESS: I don't remember seeing this
document, but I must have, but I don't remember it.
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. Do you -- does the name Accounting Data
Associates, is that familiar to you?
A. Yeah, it is, yeah.
Q. What's Accounting Data Associates?
A. Well, Dick's mom and dad originated that
firm, and they used to do taxes for people I guess
or accounting for people. I don't know what they
did, yeah. So that's all I really know about it.
Q. Do you have any understanding as to the
relationship between Accounting Data Associates and
The Highlander apartment complex?
A. Well, it'd be either the general partner
for both partnerships.
(Reporter clarification.)
THE WITNESS: I believe they are the
general partner for both partnerships.
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. And for how long have you had that
understanding?
A. Well, I don't know. I guess forever.
Q. When did you invest in The Highlander
apartment complex?
Q. And you don't recall having seen Exhibit 4,
but you don't deny having received Exhibit 4?
A. No, I don't recall or deny, huh-uh.
Q. If you look at page -- well, strike that.
Have you seen in your career documents
similar to Exhibit 4?
A. Oh, yes, of course, yeah.
Q. You understand what kind of --
A. Sure.
Q. -- paper this is?
A. I understand, yes.
Q. And what kind of document is Exhibit 4?
A. You're asking me?
Q. Yes.
A. Well, it's kind of an offering memorandum,
something you would go out to investors to try to
entice them to come into the partnership.
Q. And if you look at page 5 of 10, there's a
listing of a number of loans on this thing called
the "financial summary." Do you see that?
A. Um-hum, I do.
Q. And do you recall when you made your
investment in The Highlander that there were a
number of mortgages already on the property?
A. I don't recall, no.
Q. Do you recall that Mr. Gregersen was
proposing additional mortgages at the time you made
your investment?
A. No. Too many years ago.
Q. Do you have any recollection one way or the
other of objecting to the number of mortgages
involved in The Highlander property?
A. No, I did not. I do not.
Q. If you look at page 6 of 10, and do you see
where it says "terms" --
A. Yes.
Q. -- right at the top? And then it says,
"Partners' invested capital will have a preferential
position of a 12-percent-per-annum noncompounded
cash flow on dollars invested after payment of the
management fee to the general partner."
Did I read that first sentence of the terms
correctly?
A. I don't see the line where it says 12
percent. I see the general partner investment.
That's the area?
Q. I'm starting right at the top --
A. At the top. Oh, I'm ahead of you here.
Okay.
Q. So the "terms" --
A. Yes, I'm sorry.
Q. You see where it says, "Partners' invested
capital will have a preferential position of 12
percent per annum"?
A. Yes.
Q. Do you know what that means?
MS. PALLEN: Objection. Asked and
answered.
THE WITNESS: Yes, I guess I do.
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. Can you explain to me what that means.
A. Well, it means the first 12 percent of the
gain is the limited partner -- is the partners'.
Q. And then do you see that it says, "Cash
flow in excess of this 12-percent return will be
divided: 80 percent to the limited partners and 20
percent to the general partner"?
A. Yes, I see it.
Q. And do you understand what that means?
A. Yes.
Q. What does that mean?
A. It means the limited partners get 80
percent; general partner gets 20 percent.
Q. And then there's another -- the next
provision is "General partner's compensation." Do
you see that?
A. I do.
Q. And that says that "the general partner
will receive a fee of 2 percent of the building's
purchase price." Do you see that?
A. Yes.
Q. And it says, "In addition, the partnership
will contract with Pen-Bay Business Service for
accounting and auditing services on a competitive
basis." Do you see that?
A. Yes.
Q. Did you know what Pen-Bay Business Service
was?
A. No, I don't recall that name, Pen-Bay. For
some reason it's not clicking.
Q. Was that an entity that Mr. Gregersen had
an interest in?
MS. PALLEN: Objection. Asked and
answered.
THE WITNESS: Apparently, yes.
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. Did you have any objection to that?
A. No, not at the time. I don't even
recognize it. No.
Q. Did you have any concerns about the terms
which allowed the general partner to receive 20
percent of the cash flow in excess of the 12-percent
return?
MS. PALLEN: I'm just going to object.
Mr. Kellar said he doesn't recall seeing this
document.
But to the extent you can answer that.
MR. KEEGAN: Let me just interject. I'm
still working on the Bates number. But I found a
copy of this attached to Ms. Pallen's declaration,
which actually it's Exhibit 1 to the declaration.
It's Mr. Gregersen's declaration that he attaches it
to that declaration. Date of the declaration,
Ms. Pallen's declaration, was the 16th of November
MS. PALLEN: Okay. Thank you.
MR. ELLENBERG: Could you reread the
question.
(Record read as follows:
"Q. Did you have any concerns about
the terms which allowed the general
partner to receive 20 percent of the cash
flow in excess of the 12-percent
return?")
MS. PALLEN: Same objection.
THE WITNESS: Not to my knowledge, no.
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. Does this look like an unusual provision to
you, this 20 percent to the general partner in
excess of cash flow?
A. Yes.
Q. It is unusual?
A. Um-hum.
Q. What is your practice in terms of general
partner compensation?
A. I don't charge 20 percent.
Q. What do you charge?
A. I charge a fee going in -- I don't know
what it would be -- and a fee coming out. I don't
know what it would be. But I don't -- I don't
charge on profits like that.
Q. So when you're -- are you the general
partner -- do you own any -- are you or do you own
an interest in any general partner currently
managing real estate?
A. I have been the general partner of real
estate, uh-huh.
Q. Is it your view that general-partner
compensation is something that is negotiable with
limited partners?
A. No.
Q. It's nonnegotiable?
A. No, I don't -- I don't negotiate. I set my
fees. Gregersen sets his fees. We don't negotiate.
Q. And whatever those fees are, you can either
make your investment or not make your investment?
A. Yes.
Q. Okay. Let's --
MS. PALLEN: Ed, if you ever need to take a
break or something, just let us know.
THE WITNESS: I need to go to Santa Cruz
pretty soon.
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. Let's mark as Exhibit 5 a document entitled
"The Highlander Apartments, Central Investments
partnership agreement." Now, we already had this as
exhibit -- I think it was Exhibit 1, but it didn't
have Mr. Kellar's signature. So I'm going to just
put this one in just so we can identify Mr. Kellar's
signature.
(Exhibit No. 5 is marked.)
THE WITNESS: (Reviewing document.)
MR. ELLENBERG: Unfortunately this document
does not have a Bates number.
MR. KEEGAN: I can get you one for that.
MR. ELLENBERG: Okay. But what I want to
say is, if you go --
MR. KEEGAN: You have -- you have a special
one that shows his signature?
MR. ELLENBERG: Yeah.
MR. KEEGAN: Take me a long time to find
it.
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. So if you go -- if you go -- and it's not
going to help if you give me the Bates number
because it's not on here. If you go to about
halfway through, you'll see what I think is the
signature of you and your wife.
A. (Reviewing document.)
Q. Kim, what I'm going to do, because I'm
seeing as I'm flipping through this, I'm going to
with counsel's permission replace this exhibit at
some point before the end of the day with one that
redacts everyone's Social Security numbers.
MS. PALLEN: I was just about to say the
same thing.
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. I'll have my assistant do that.
Do you see your signature?
A. I do, yes, uh-huh.
Q. And you recognize your signature?
A. I do.
Q. And you recognize your wife's signature?
A. Yes.
Q. And do you recognize the document as the
partnership agreement as of September 1, 1977?
A. Yes, apparently. I haven't read it through
and through. Yes, it's probably the one.
Q. Was it your practice in 1977 to review a
partnership agreement before you signed it?
A. Yes.
Q. And do you recall how much money you
invested in Central Investments?
Q. And back in 1977 can we agree 110,000 was a
lot of money?
A. 110,000 is always a lot of money, yes.
Q. I'd like to say that's a lot of money in
San Jose.
And are you certain that you would have
read the partnership agreement pretty carefully
before investing $110,000 into the partnership?
A. Yes. And I trusted my friend, Dick
Gregersen, yes.
Q. Was Mr. Gregersen available to answer
questions if you had any?
A. 50 years ago, I really don't know. I'm
sure yes, probably.
Q. And do you believe you read the entire
partnership agreement before you signed it?
A. Yes, probably, yeah.
Q. And if you look at Section 1.02 which is on
the third page of the document --
A. Um-hum, yes.
Q. -- and that's entitled "purpose of the
partnership"?
A. Yes, I see it.
Q. And is that an unusual provision to you?
A. No.
Q. And did you understand what the purpose of
the partnership was?
A. Yes.
Q. What did you understand was the purpose of
the partnership?
A. To make money.
Q. To make money through real estate
investment?
A. Investments, yes.
Q. And that included all the various ways that
you can make money with respect to real estate.
Right?
MS. PALLEN: I would object. Vague and
ambiguous as to "all the various ways."
THE WITNESS: The only way that I really
know is appreciation.
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. You could also make money through
dividends, correct, payment of distributions?
A. Distributions?
Q. Yes.
A. Yes.
Q. And did you understand that the -- that the
investment could include loaning money in connection
with this particular real estate investment?
A. No, I don't -- I don't understand that
portion, no.
Q. Was there anything that you're aware of
that precluded the partnership loaning money?
MS. PALLEN: Do you mean in the agreement?
BY MR. ELLENBERG:
Q. In the agreement that you're aware of.
A. No. The partnership is supposed to use the
money for the building and paying the costs of the
building and capital improvements. That's what the
money is for, right.
Q. And you knew from the get-go -- did you
believe -- "get-go" is a little bit colloquial.
Did you believe from the execution of the
partnership agreement that the general partner was
prohibited from using partnership funds to loan
money?
A. Well, it is something that a general
partner of a partnership is supposed to use money
for that building or giving money back to the
distributions of the partners. That's the only two
things that money from The Highlander is supposed to
go for.
Q. And was there something in particular in
the partnership agreement that you thought
prohibited the lending of money by the general
partner?
